main_comment: What other skills do you think most programmer overlook when just starting out?
replies:
I’ve been coding, starting what little I could at the age of 10 with the information and hardware I had available, 40 years ago.  I would have killed for something like Stack Overflow.  The information I had available until I was an adult was limited to what I could walk to get at the public library (school and local city library) and walking distance bookstores.  I had to learn a lot of stuff from what I had, and then translate/find parallels to what I had to work with in practice.  That’s one skill that transfers incredibly well regardless of time/space/platform, and I’d need to take a bit of time to count how many I’ve worked with.

Here is one that can help avoid needless time spent debugging later, that also is 100% transferrable: ensure all variables are explicitly initialized to a valid terminal state as early as possible.  What do I mean by that?
1.  If it isn’t otherwise changed to indicate that something was successful, it should be set to an error value.  This is what’s returned by default.
2.  If it isn’t otherwise changed to indicate something failed (any operation succeeds unless that in particular fails) set it to a success value.  I prefer #1, less room to go wrong: use that FIRST because you can always go back later.  Just set it to a generic “error code not explicitly stated” general error: you should never return a general error: what good is a general error?
3.  Initialize any arrays or variables to a known-good safe state at the very beginning, so you have 100% repeatability every time you call that function.  This is even more important to remember when you work with non-deterministic systems, because all the determinism you can muster helps debugging be far more efficient.

Getting into these habits will save you countless hours of debugging for what are often the dumbest of mistakes of execution or misunderstanding of the problem.  A 100% repeatable bug is the easiest bug to identify it is a bug, and  where it is at, and how to fix: accept no substitutes in your code by implementing this habit by default!  Code reviewers of any value will love you for it.  So will customers!  The most obnoxious software as a user is the software that you wonder if you will have it work correctly or at least the same way, given the same input, every time.
optimization;)
Files

I guess a good habit it HOW you actually learn.

Learning *consistent,* every day (1-4 hours), WITH hands on (in the editor or on a website for practical coding), is most important for the very first months of a developers career.

Just to build that foundation of basic knowledge, after which you may get more interesting tasks (and therefore more motivation).
Soft Skills, Cloud stuff, the Mathematics behind coding,etc.
@Lucas Premat 👍
@Shis One example is Game Development.
@The Coding Mentor Absolutely. I feel like a blabbering wreck compared to our senior devs!!

Living water.

Great list. 

One ‘habit’ I would suggest is to ‘take an empirical view’. Come up with theories. Do experiments. Disprove those theories. Basically, apply the scientific method. So much of programming is about discovery, not invention. Once you have discovered a way that works, a theory that seems correct, you can experiment to find out why, and iterate towards a way that works faster, less memory, less code etc. 

That’s why physicists make the best programmers 😉

A second I would consider, somewhat related to the first, is ‘knowing when to stop’. One of my teachers said to me ‘a program is never finished’. You can always spend more time refactoring, tidying up, adding more tests, trying different libraries or versions of libraries, polishing the code; but in a production environment you have to know when to stop - perfection being the enemy of good enough. And not good enough being the enemy of acceptable. 

You have to put a limit on your OCD. 

A final one for consideration; the right tool for the job. This could be considered under ‘domain knowledge’? Anyways, this was a favourite saying of another of my teachers. They pointed out that using the right tool can be 100 times faster (in dev time) than using the wrong one. Like if you have a hammer, every problem is treated like a nail. It’s always worth hunting around to see if there already exists a tool for your problem.  Eg I once had 85 lines of code replaced by one line of (very cunning) sql. It’s a trade off between time spent looking/asking vs time spent coding!

I can’t help but add a further one. Breadth and depth of knowledge. Spend some time getting to know the full stack. Read about, I don’t know, Networks - how do they work? Databases - how do they actually work, web servers? What’s really going on? If a bug leads you down a rabbit hole to some issue with eg DNS settings or port mappings - take a few extra minutes to find out more about them while you are there - rather than just the absolute minimum to fix what you need. You will be better prepared next time!
Reading Documentation, no one will teach you that and is really important

7:25: Software tools and efficiency. Use of IDEs, libraries, version control, command line usage, knowledge of frameworks and modules.

main_comment: In my view, "domaing knowledge" is to know about the market specifics of what you're working on. For example, I work in a Real Estate Fintech Startup, so the domain knowledge here is knowing about Real Estate market specifics. I actually think that, in some cases, it is better to have a Junior programmer with Domain Knowledge over a Senior programmer with no knowledge of the market the company is in
replies: @vulpixelful Your comments are entirely off-topic. Your personal choice does not define the whole industry.
@Vs Sm Well that's how we work, and we're compensated well for that so that's all I can say ✌🏾
@vulpixelful You are either an architect/dev or a domain specialist. You cannot be both, and there is no need for that even in a startup.

@Vs Sm Again, in small startups that's usually the senior devs bothering the Product Owner and architecting it themselves. In smaller orgs with less headcount, senior devs aren't just implementers, we also are the architects

@vulpixelful For a system design you need an architect, not a simple dev. In any case a domain specialist can be interviewed to get the specifics. You don't need to know everything, you need to learn how to ask right questions. This is what I do everyday as as dev, it's called translating business requirements to technical specifications.
Yes, I'm in a fintech startup too and this is true. In a bigger company, that may be "someone else's job" but not in a startup lol. The domain drives the system design.

That is indeed what is called domain knowledge. I work in educational software, and my coworkers with a background in education are the ones with domain knowledge, even though I have far more expertise in software.
@John Bennett Sorry, you are too wordy. Word diarrhea is not the best way of communication.

@John Bennett Exactly. When you don't bother getting a proper education, your life in programming is very hard like yours. When you have one, it's just yet another task you've been solving for years. My attitude is education. education and education. Your attitude is neither education, nor experience, otherwise you would know that any interface is paid for by a Marketing Department and not by talented UX/UI designers.

@Vs Sm if you are a coder, then fine. If you are what I would call a programmer, you need a lot more. At my last job, my assignment was "improve the accuracy of the handwriting recognizer". It was my job to figure out how to do this. It involved a combination of my knowledge, asking my colleagues, research and a whole lot of experimentation. Most programmers get more direction than this, but a lot of important details are left up to them. Your attitude is why every retail interface I have ever seen was somewhere between bad and truly horrible.

@JulianoGheller Before you get a specific role you have to get a proper education which let you get specialized in any field you want. The problem is that you don't have one and that's why cannot see a bigger picture.

@Vs Sm I see it in another way. If your mindset is that you should only learn and execute things in your specific role, thats right (you can even call yourself a "Specialist"), but anyone who is curious enough to exceed your pre-determined attributions to contribute in as many ways possible (called a "Generalist"), is, in my opinion, way more valuable. Be whatever you want, but, notoriously, these individuals have a way higher chance to succeed just because they have a bigger range of skills
@Devashish Mishra Proper education, then domain is a context only.
@JulianoGheller For priorities there are  PM and BA regardless of your position. You are just doing someone's else job you are not paid for.
What's the best way of gaining domain knowledge?
աɧԹԵՏԹρρ ʍe ՌԾա✍🏿✍🏿🔝

@Vs Sm exactly, it's not the technical things that differ, but the understanding of the priorities and the things that really would improve the product as a whole, that's why I used the "Junior with this knowledge > Senior without (for some cases) eu" argument. My point is that this Junior would have way more autonomy and direction of what needs to be done than the Senior, that would know HOW, but not what.

This is just a silly bias. How an input field or SQL query differ in real estate? I’ve been working in finance area for years and still have no idea what they talk about. For all your questions there is always a BA or someone from the business side.

I agree. It might be just a fintech thing. The knowledge of how the finance part works is a really important part in being able to even know where to start. It does cut both ways though into things like specific routines that do finance calculations, or audit reporting. I know in my company there's people who've done these for years and just know the entire range of possibilities in those specific areas
